content: ProblemClimate change is the most urgent global issue on humanity's agenda, with its impacts becoming increasingly evident in our daily lives. It encompasses a wide range of potential damages, including water and food security, scarcity, conflicts, migration, and more. The primary cause of climate change is the accumulation of greenhouse gases - carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and nitrous oxides (N2O) - in the atmosphere, leading to an increase in global temperatures. Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, mainly resulting from human activities, are the major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions.Concerning climate change, some companies or organizations continue to resort to data manipulation, either by minimizing their negative impacts or providing misleading information, despite claiming to reduce or prevent adverse effects. This complicates the issue further and makes it challenging to track real progress.Some companies use a tactic known as "greenwashing," employing deceptive and incomplete information on labels, packaging, or marketing materials solely to create an environmentally friendly image. This practice hinders consumers from being directed towards genuinely sustainable and eco-friendly products, overshadowing the actual problems. While regulations create a foundation for tracking GHG data, current climate data collection methods are based on centralized databases and are susceptible to data manipulation. Atmospheric carbon measurement is primarily conducted by central governments and large research organizations, mainly due to resource access and their use as central policy instruments.
